result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Samuel-Jeshua John Bardenwerper

records.addlTxt: Calendar call on December 13, 2022 at 09:15 am.
Initial Scheduling Order

11:00 AM Prosecuting attorney Emmeline Lee appeared by video for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Samuel-Jeshua John Bardenwerper appeared by phone.  Attorney Ryan W O'Hara appeared by video for Samuel-Jeshua John Bardenwerper. Defense stipulates to Defendants identity. Officer Ashley Lervik sworn in and testified by video. Court takes Judicial Notice of 11CF517. State moves for bind over, Defense objects without argument. Court finds probable cause and binds Defendant over for filing of an Information. Information filed, copy to Defendant, reading waived. Defendants attorney pleads not guilty and jury trial to be set.
Preliminary hearing on August 9, 2022 at 11:00 am.

10:14 AM Prosecuting attorney Noah M Tylenda appeared by video for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Samuel-Jeshua John Bardenwerper appeared by video. Preliminary hearing requested and time limits waived. Hearing by video.
Preliminary hearing scheduled for August 9, 2022 at 11:00 am.

Complaint filed, copy to defendant, charges and penalties advised, rights given, reading waived. Signature bond of $3000 with conditions of not to consume or possess a controlled substance without a valid prescription and in prescribed amounts only. Absolute sobriety. Not to possess paraphernalia. Not to possess any identification of others.
